title: Will Rafael Nadal win the 2022 Men's French Open?
preds: Now into the finals. He is still getting old and an injury is more than possible, so only going 80%

He's never lost the French Open final. This is his favorite tournament and the courts he knows best -- he is at 111-3 at Roland Garros.  But his contender is 10-15 years younger and has excellent record in those courts (elite clay court player). This time around, Nadal was also in the toughest draw which included Djokovic world's no 1, Alcaraz, world's no. 2  and Zverev.  Odds are with Nadal but in sports anything can happen -- look at where he is now, something we didn't think possible 3 months ago.
Not sure he will win. The game he won by forfeit was going reasonably close until the other player broke his ankle.
Odds imply an 84% chance now that Rafa is through the semis: https://www.oddschecker.com/tennis/french-open/mens
Just going to copy bookie odds because not doing so has burned me in the past.
He is a big favorite. Hard to say as I am Norwegian 😀
Made it to the finals as his opponent got injured. Don't know yet who he will be playing but those left ranked significantly lower.
He made it to the finals! And his opponents are substantially lower ranked.

Nadal hasn't gone beyond 4 sets in the rounds leading up to the final - first 3 wins in straight sets, next 2 in 4 sets and the semi-finals - his opponent retired after 2 sets...looking at 2 potential challengers - head2head, nadal hasn't played one of them and the other he has won prior matches

Of the two potential finalists, Nadal is more experienced and has won 20 grand slams, while Ruud and Cilic only have one between the both of them. Nadal has shown good form in spite of his foot injury, he has a higher chance of taking this final.

Disaster. For Zverev. A shocking twist to the ankle after a slide wide to the forehand has suddenly stopped Zverevs chances in the semi-final. And it was his to lose I think (which he may have done anyway as he started double-faulting trying to take the second set).
Actually I’m still not sure about this. It will be a very tough semi-final
Nadal on track to win in the semifinals
He was sandbagging. Yeah, he was truthfully in pain, but  man, what a sand-bagger.
Not possible to make a older version of self proof new,

The win against Djokovic was big. Now with four people remaining, the base rate is 25% but Nadal has shown he can take out the top seed and we know from history he can win here. Going to 2/3rds chance.

Looks like the magic of Roland Garros is working on Nadal again and he’s found some unexpected form, raising his fragments against Djokovic. Hes in the semis so a base 25% chance of winning.  But with his French Open record and suddenly finding form, it’s probably a bit higher than that.  not quite 50% yet though.

Nadal's comeback is impressive! Djokovic and Alcaraz are out. Nadal will play Zverev in the semifinals on Friday. Zverev never beat a top-10 player at a Grand Slam before yesterday, so I think it's likely Nadal will win in the semifinals. And if he does, I think it's likely he'd win the finals, based on the fact that he would be playing a lower-ranked player (from what I can tell - I'm not a big tennis fan).
Next stop A. Zverev. It's been a long night session that Nadal obviously better coped with. However, repercussions into the next match must be expected.
Quite a day, both other favorites in Djokovic and Alcaraz were eliminated
Two more matches. Assuming a 2/3 chance on each, about 44%.   The sports books are much much more bullish Rafa, with odds closer to 70%: https://www.oddschecker.com/tennis/french-open/mens
Impressive, extraordinary performance today against the world No. 1 Djokovic.
Still don’t think he can do it. But a lot less sure now.
Must have been an amazing game to watch - the crowd loves Nadal. Did we underestimate the King of Clay?
Nadal has almost won the first set of qf against Djokovic. Could become a long and thrilling evening. The longer the worse for Nadal, I suppose.
Betting on mind vs matter o this one. Quarter finals match against Djokovic today.  French Open is Nadal's favorite tournament and his spirits have been on fire since the start.
Have my doubts that he can get past Novak.
I have to remain rational and say the chances are. Low, even though I was  impressed that he made it past an increasingly capable Auger-Aliassime. That he still has even a chance says quite a lot.
He has made it to the quarterfinals, but now the rest is going to be extremely challenging.
I’d put him at no better than 50/50 for each of the three remaining matches. My heart wants him to win but, analytically, it’s unlikely.
Didn’t look strong in round 4 and has Djokovic next. Decreasing odds.

I was a bit too optimistic with my initial prediction, so have knocked it back a bit considering his recent injuries and because he's facing Djokovic in the quarters. If he can get through this match, then he'll have a good chance of winning.

Have to move Nadal’s chances up a little after an incredible performance - he still seems able to lift his game to the highest level at the most critical moments. Will the five-setter affect his recovery or ongoing issues with his foot? So far he is defying the odds and hanging on with typical grit.
Performing better than expected.  Likely to head to quarter finals where hed be facing Novak Djokovic. But Nadal is getting most of the press.

He’s been looking so sharp in the early rounds. Hoping a bit.   Also this (completely irrelevant, but nice): https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/roland-garros/2022/zinedine-zidane-backs-rafael-nadal-to-win-it-all-at-the-french-open-despite-younger-talent-being-pre_sto8953589/story-amp.shtml

Performed surprisingly well in the second round, reaching 300 career grand slam.  But he has tougher matches ahead, a "chronically injured left foot that sometimes hurts so much he cannot play" "A stress fracture in one of his ribs, suffered at Indian Wells in March, cut short his clay-court season and has left him with far less preparation than usual ahead of the French Open (which he says is his favorite tournament so he has the motivation). "His knees are often on the edge of balky. He is two weeks shy of his 36th birthday, an age that, a generation ago, would have effectively stopped him from contending for, much less winning, Grand Slam titles. He limped through the final set of his last match at the Italian Open, a three-set loss in the round of 16" The general idea is that he would not be at the French Open if he didn't think he could win.  Novak Djokovic	is still ranking no. 1 followed by Carlos Alcaraz as no. 2 with Nadal coming at no. 3 in odds of winning. Tomorrow match against B. van de Zandschulp should be very telling.  https://au.sports.yahoo.com/tennis-2022-rafael-nadal-300-grand-slam-wins-historic-feat-french-open-021337571.html https://lastwordonsports.com/tennis/2022/05/26/french-open-day-6-predictions-van-de-zandschulp-vs-nadal/
Current betting odds 21%. Looking sharp in early rounds

Reminding that looking at Nadals history about 2/3rds of his wins have been at the French Open so there is something about it that suits him.  Balance this with the draw looking like he could be up against Djokovic is the quarter finals ( assuming they both get through the next couple of rounds) so it looks like he has a quite a hard draw this time.

seeing as Nadal made it through the round of 64 yesterday and is now on to the round of 32 i'm upping my estimate.  both players faced previously he had not played before and that trend continues with his next challenger - although next challenger is ranked higher in world rankings

Even with foot injury, he is King of Clay and Rolland Garros is his mental safe space ( for a player who is in his head). But Djokovic beat him there before and has great clay stats; and Alcaraz is on a tear, sooooo….Tsitsipas can also do clay. If not for the injury, would have gone to 55%.

upping estimate slightly as Nadal did start the open and won in the round of 128 in straight sets (6-2, 6-2, 6-2) - historically, Nadal had beaten his round of 128 opponent once prior - he has never played his round of 64 opponent however that opponet is ranked lower than his previous one...
Sports books have Nadal down to like 15% - ish
If Nadal decides to and/or is able to compete, he is supposed to meet Djokovic in the quarterfinals already. https://www.atptour.com/en/scores/current/roland-garros/520/draws
Following the crowd down a bit.
The injury doesn't seem to be behind him, but we've seen athletes play through worse. Downgrading because there is fierce competition in Djokovic. There would have been even without the injury.

RAFAEL NADAL SHOWS FEW SIGNS OF INJURY SCARE AS HE PRACTICES AT FRENCH OPEN IN FRONT OF HUGE CROWD
 Rafael Nadal showed few signs of his chronic foot condition that flared up at the Italian Open as he practiced at Roland-Garros for the first time ahead of the French Open. Nadal spoke following the Rome event of the pain he was feeling in his foot, throwing doubt over his participation in Paris. https://www.eurosport.co.uk/tennis/roland-garros/2022/rafael-nadal-shows-few-signs-of-injury-scare-as-he-practices-at-french-open-in-front-of-huge-crowd_sto8930282/story.shtml

Nadal has confirmed today that he's going to play in the French Open and is training at his place in Mallorca. But, he's still in pain. I had thought it likely that he would heal better than this by now, but that doesn't seem to be happening. It's not looking good for him for the French Open. https://www.nytimes.com/2022/05/12/sports/tennis/nadal-italian-open-shapovalov.html
Simply don't see it now, in particular due to recurrent injuries.
Looks like betting odds still have him at about 25% to win, and my own subjective judgement is more like 5%, so I'll take the midpoint

I shouldn't rule him out completely, but with Djokovic now having returned to form, and Alcaraz still improving within the top 10, the odds are no longer anywhere near in Nadal's favour, given his known injury issues. Best of luck to him though.
Most recent outing shows he is still struggling.
He's been doing relatively well in his last 5 games post-injury, winning up to 60% of his games. Balancing my inside and outside view equally.
keeping my probability low - based on recent injuries/news, i don't know if he'll start the tournament - but will adjust if he does

Ugh. I want to give a lower prediction but Nadal seems to be uncharacteristically low-keying his injury (he and Djokovic are usually such prima donnas. primo uomos?) so maybe he's not as bad off as the articles seem to be making him.https://twitter.com/TennisChannel/status/1524862662718505011
Now talking about retirement after loss at Italian Open.
Latest loss in Rome and admission from Nadal suggests this is impossible, due to injury and recovery.
Sadly moving back down - I think his niggling injuries will just prove too much for him to reach peak form in time

Moving up slightly, as his win over Isner shows a steady return to form. It’s a fair point that it takes time to recover not just fitness but critically match fitness too, as we’ve seen with Djokovic. But there is only a little over a week to go and by Nadal’s own admission he is rushing to get back to form. It still looks a step too far this time bearing in mind Alcaraz, Djokovic and others, but he’s getting slightly closer to evens.

Going back up a bit. I think people are taking the "Nadal is in pain every single day" article out of context - this isn't about his recent injury, and hasn't prevented him from playing well before. Nadal isn't looking like his absolute best but is just coming back so we should expect better form at RG. His main contenders are Djokovic, who isn't looking like his best either this year, and Carlos Alcaraz Garfia who is in great shape but doesn't have the same grand slam experience.
Aftermath of Madrid leaves his chances slightly reduced; niggling injury preventing his full fitness and ability, Alcaraz coming into form with renewed confidence.

Alcaraz has proven he is in better shape and rhythm than any other play on Clay right now.  Nadal has stated he is in pain practically all the time (https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/tennis/rafael-nadal-says-injuries-leave-him-in-pain-every-single-day/ar-AAWZBX2) and he has missed some of the prep tournaments coming to the French Open.  He is down but not out yet.
Recent Madrid performance suggests Nadal still competitive but not quite at the levels to win a major tournament just yet.

Nadal out in qf of 2022 Madrid Open v C. Alcaraz, 2-6, 6-1, 3-6 https://www.google.de/search?q=Madrid+Open Nadal appears to be in weak shape, probably too many unforced faults, too low "Win % on first serve" (58% for Nadal v 69% for Alcaraz) and break point conversion (only 3 out of 9 break points for Nadal v 4/5 for Alcaraz).  Too much drama, even in the round of 16 the day before: https://au.sports.yahoo.com/tennis-2022-disbelief-rafa-nadal-drama-madrid-open-213447253.html  Despite a very strong phase throughout 2nd set, Nadal appears to have lost his "killer" instinct and fails to win crucial points at crucial time. Perhaps time for taking a longer break or even thinking about ending the career at peak. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1436979  "Rafael Nadal says injuries leave him in pain 'every single day'" https://edition.cnn.com/2022/05/06/tennis/rafael-nadal-suffering-chronic-injury-spt-intl/index.html "Awesome Alcaraz Takes Out Nadal In Madrid" https://www.atptour.com/en/news/nadal-alcaraz-madrid-2022-friday "Diego Schwartzman gives thoughts on Rafael Nadal's French Open title chances" https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Rafael_Nadal/113471/diego-schwartzman-gives-thoughts-on-rafael-nadal-s-french-open-title-chances/
Based on his footwork and length of his bangs, I predict that his right eye will twitch wildly at minute 22 of the match.
Tricky one as Nadal needs more recovery time but will maintain forecast for now.
Rafa is back at Madrid, moving well and getting court time. Meanwhile Djokovic is taking longer to settle back into form. I’m increasing the odds.
good momentum but Novak d is back in and has something to prove.
Tricky one this, will hedge lower for now and revise as we go along.

Stepped on a tennis court for the first time in 4 weeks today for some soft training. Still a lot of uncertainty if he'll be in top form for the French Open which starts in less than 4 weeks.
https://www.express.co.uk/sport/tennis/1597504/Rafael-Nadal-steps-on-court-Spaniard-injury-update-tennis-news

"Post the Indian Wells, Nadal was to skip the 2022 Miami Masters and make his Clay debut at the 2022 Monte-Carlo Masters but the fracture forced him to skip the event in Monaco where he is a record 11-time champion. With a massive doubt over his participation in Clay events this season, it looked unlikely that Nadal will be fully ready before the 2022 French Open where he is chasing his 14th French Open title and 22nd major.
[...]
However, good news has certainly presented itself. Nadal hit the clay courts recently for his first practice session as he eyes an return to the Tour quickly. While he will miss this week’s events as well, the Serbian Open in Belgrade and the Barcelona Open where he is the defending champion, Nadal can look at it as another 2 weeks of practice before he can return to action in May as he had initially planned to play only in Monte-Carlo and Barcelona before the injury ruined his plans."
https://firstsportz.com/tennis-news-what-an-illusion-rafael-nadal-ecstatic-after-having-his-first-practice-session-on-clay/ " ‘Real shot to win it,’ Greg Rusedski names Stefanos Tsitsipas as one of the huge favorites to win the French Open along with Djokovic, Nadal, and Alcaraz"
https://firstsportz.com/tennis-news-real-shot-to-win-it-greg-rusedski-names-stefanos-tsitsipas-as-one-of-the-huge-favorites-to-win-the-french-open-along-with-djokovic-nadal-and-alcaraz/ Too much time missing the court, too many names as serious aspirants this year.
Only if Nadal advances to the 2022 Madrid tournament semis at least (or is going to participate without worsening the injury  in the first place) I shall assign a 24% chance to him again.
Very difficult to say, even if he enters.  Will keep a close eye on this one.
Didn't click the number - logic the same

As a baseline, Nadal has won 13 of the last 17 French Opens. He did not win last year though. His play style is favorable for a clay court, which is why he tends to win at the French Open. He is coming off of an injury which could a) prevent him from playing or b) hinder his ability to win. Even if he does play, there is a chance he is rusty from taking time off to recover. At 35, Nadal is more prone to injuries during the match as well. Assuming a 95% chance he enters the French Open
A 10% chance that he withdraws from injury
A 75% chance that he has sufficiently gotten the rust off in other games before the French Open
A 60% chance of him winning, if all of the above go well
Total = 38%

I'm going to shift towards what the sports books are giving for odds; they are probably doing a better job of weighing the severity of his injury than I can add given my own knowledge at the current moment
Will leave as is for now but will monitor closely.
Stick with this for now but will review regularly.

I'm still going with Nadal as more likely than not to win this. He has come back time and again from countless injuries. Yes, he's skipping Barcelona, but that gives him more time to heal properly before the French Open. I wouldn't want to play a match 3 weeks after a rib fracture, would you? Some day, he will start to lose a lot, but we haven't seen that day yet.

With Nadal skipping Barcelona with a rib fracture he will be coming into the tournament with several different injuries over the last season or two. Even if the injuries do not prevent him from completing all the matches needed to make it to the final at the French Open, lingering pain during key sport actions (swinging the racket for the ribs, running around court for foot injury) and lack of practice in major tournaments recently should decrease his chances.  I know Nadal is usually as close to a sure thing as you can get in tennis in the French Open on clay. But with the mounting injuries this year, an aging body that is less able to bounce back quickly to these injuries, and skipping several tournament this year as a result of the injuries it seems more likely to me at this point for him to be forced out through injury than winning it all. Even if his body holds up enough to get through the matches I see the injuries having a lingering effect on his ability to perform. I am leaving a 10% margin of error because if he is able to work through the injuries there is no knowing what one of the Greatest tennis players ever can do in one of his most comfortable environments. I just see it as unlikely with his age that he will be able to recover from all the injuries and return to full form quick enough to go all the way in the tournament.

https://www.express.co.uk/sport/tennis/1594962/Rafael-Nadal-Barcelona-French-Open-rib-injury-tennis-news Have to wait and see at this point. Pulled out of Barca, seems very injuried. Could pull out of French or be too hurt to play effectively. With Djokovic on his heels the chances are dimished greatly now until we know more about the injury!
not changing probability yet - but Nadal did just pull out of a tournament in Barcelona - https://www.ibtimes.com/rafael-nadal-injury-when-will-21-time-grand-slam-champion-play-next-3472437

Odds post-injury really didn't change much, I was anticipating a larger shift. When from 110 to 120. Odds would be between 43% and 46% depending on adjustment. I'm adjusting downward on the slim chance that he doesn't compete at all. In my understanding right now, mostly based on how mid-match retirements are treated for betting, if he doesn't compete in the tournament then bets are voided, so that probably isn't being priced into the betting odds currently.  https://www.sportsbettingdime.com/tennis/french-open-odds/
He has skipped the Barcelona Open.  https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/nadal-skips-barcelona-open-return-date-still-uncertain-2022-04-12/

"... while Moving Day is generally an opportunity for golfers to put together strong efforts as a means of jumping into the top 10, Woods looked as if he might be better off sealed in bubble wrap before returning to the course Sunday."
https://www.cbssports.com/golf/news/2022-masters-tiger-woods-score-sputtering-putter-leads-to-career-worst-round-of-78-at-augusta-national/
https://www.cbssports.com/golf/news/tiger-woods-tracker-score-at-masters-2022-despite-career-worst-weekend-tiger-shows-guts-finishing-72-holes/live/ Coming back after injury is hard and will be hard for Nadal. Coming back at the top of the heap is even harder.
Alcaraz is the mini-Nadal and he has the momentum going into the French Open.

Repeating my forecast. He has come back from countless injuries before, and the French Open will be on clay, which is his favorite. But, there are a lot of other good players out there, too, and some day, he will lose to one of them.
Currently at 6/4 odds. He wants it. https://www.oddschecker.com/tennis/french-open/mens
Reaffirming although dropped slightly as little scope for recovery time.

Question now is whether Nadal can prepare for the French Open after having to miss the start of the clay season after a stress fracture in one of his ribs. He had to be out 4-6 weeks, missing Miami, Monte Carlo tournaments. He's scheduled to play on the Barcelona Open which starts on April 18.

maintaining low probability right now that Nadal even starts the FO - https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Rafael_Nadal/111907/patrick-mouratoglou-explains-challenges-rafael-nadal-faces-in-french-open-preparation/
He's been out with an injury and will be recovering until mid-April
Dropped down a little due to required recovery time.
No change in his reported status.  Dropping down a bit more to 25% given the recovery he will need to make without much time to do so.
I'll reduce a little as the current fitness or otherwise of Nadal is not totally clear.
He's still at +110 (!?) and I'm still thinking that a 48% implied probability of him winning is too high.
Nadal injury at Indian Wells doesn't bode well.  Look for whether he tries to go at Madrid.
Although the Vegas favorite, does not mean over 50% chance. With defending champ Djokovic in field, COVID, rest of field, I am on the lower side of scale.
An incredible track record at the French Open, so even with an injury, will be very tough to beat.

Well, despite not winning at Indian Wells as well as the rib injury, odds-makers still have him at +110. The scuttlebutt says his "of course I lost, I've got a broken rib" sour grapes. I don't know about that, but if the betting markets still put him at 50/50 for a win, that's good enough for me.

He won the last Australian open, and he won almost all of the past editions. So based on that I'd estimate around 80% chance. On the other hand, it's unsure how his ﻿injury will affect his performance, and Djokovic (his biggest opponent) wasn't present at the Australian open, but might be at Roland Garros.
Dropping 15% on news of the rib injury
Nadal out for at least 4-6 weeks after a stress fracture in his rib cage.  Even if he is healthy enough to play at French Open, it will be tough to win it unfortunately.

Ooof! Perhaps I'm over-correcting; the betting markets have his odds down, but not nearly as much as I'd thought they'd be. "Rafael Nadal suffers rib injury that may impact his French Open status: 'This is not good news'" https://www.cbssports.com/tennis/news/rafael-nadal-suffers-rib-injury-that-may-impact-his-french-open-status-this-is-not-good-news/
heavy adjustment down...with the report of Nadal's injury...they are saying out for 4-6 weeks...FO starts in 8...low likelihood he enters, even lower he wins, but....
I think the betting markets are probably closer to reality than the base rate on this question

Bringing this down after seeing the news Nadal will be out for 6 weeks with a rib fracture. French open starts 22nd May, but there are additional risks now:
- May not fully recover in time
- May be out of practice to more of a degree
He's tough but getting old. I'm take the field. Been outstanding at the French open. But nobody beats father time.
Stress rib fracture.  He should recover in time but it makes it less likely he will compete and compete well.

0.72 winning rate at grand slam tournaments https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal_career_statistics#:~:text=Nadal%20has%20won%2036%20ATP,Novak%20Djokovic's%2083.2%25%20winning%20percentage.
he lost in 2021

he is still recovering from an injury > -5% points
probability winning now: 0.67

https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/60817261
Very injury prone but has proven immense bouncebackability

Recent injury may mean he won't show up at all.  If he does, he won't have had much time to get ready.  He may also break again in the middle of the tournament, or have to be more gingerly in running about and bashing the ball and such.  Lots of things, in other words, could help him not win.  Staying low for a while, pending developments.
It's in jeopardy now due to a stress rib fracture. https://www.tsn.ca/rafael-nadal-rib-injury-french-open-1.1774854
Nadal has a cracked rib that will keep him out of the game for 4 to 6 weeks, leaving just 2 to 4 weeks for him to practice and prepare for the French Open.

Updated injury news, would suggest either might have only just recovered by time of the competition and lack a suitable run up to the event or injury complications could worsen and force him to miss the competition altogether
Injury puts chances lower, but not (yet) below 50%. https://au.sports.yahoo.com/tennis-2022-fans-devastated-rafa-nadal-revelation-195624978.html
Reported breathing problems at a recent contest.

The base rate is 13 of the last 17, or about 75%. His dominance at the French open seems to be attributed to the clay surface according to some sources online. However the last time he was ranked this low in 2015 and 2016 he did not win the French open either year. So I'm adjusting downward to 40%. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal_career_statistics#ATP_Ranking
Reaffirming forecast with Nadal as the strong favorite.

Form over his career at French open is phenomenal and has had his best start to his season ever this season, Djokovic not being able to play, uncertainty over Medvedev who would be seen as big threats may further strengthen his case, his injury is a concern, but with time to recuperate would still give him a very strong chance.
since 2005 - RN has won the French open 13 times including 2020 - however he is also currently ranked 6th in the world  - inital prediction 60% but when the brackets are released that may change
He's reportedly taking time off beforehand so as to not exacerbate his foot

Update: If recent wins against Opelka and Alcaraz are any indicator then his drive and form will hold for the French. But a minor injury and uncertainty over Djokovic or Medvedev are uncertainties that remain. Slight upward adjustment.
High previous win rate (13/19) and great momentum this year
He was discussing his foot pain during this week's tournament so I need to give more weight to him dropping out or playing hurt.
Uncertain of Djokovic with vaccines and Medveev due to Ukraine,  Nadal wants to break the GS tie he currently is in,  coming off of Australia win,  home court.

Of Nadal’s 16 French Open appearances he has won 13 of them (81%). His main threat seems to be Novak Dojokovic who beat Nadal last year (2021) in the French Open but has lost 7 of those 9 matchups in that tournament total. Also, Dojokovic’s vaccination status may be a factor in his attendance at the Open (this is unlikely, but still a consideration). I’m not going to modify Nadal’s 81% win record in the initial stages of this question.
Historic precedent and momentum gives Nadal an advantage, Djokovic seems out of the equation. All this gives Nadal good chances of taking the win here.
3/17:  I have no idea about tennis.  I'm leveraging the crowd forecast and gambling odds to make this forecast.  Currently -275.

Nadal is the King of Clay. He is going into the French Open with great momentum.  If he remains injury free, he should be able to win again.  Tennis players who are also great on clay courts are Djokovic, Tsisipas and Thiem.  None have a momentum going into the French Open at this point in time.

Nadal has won 13/20 French Opens and in the last 10 years alone has won 7 of them. He is the sportsbook favourite as well. This season he's also very hot (17 match winning streak -- this does matter in sports in my view). So it seems the odds are in his favour to win again. Risk will be Djokovic -- who does have a winning record over Nadal in their career head-to-heads, has won the French Open twice (including last year) and is potentially looking for redemption after the Australian Open fiasco.

Nadal has won 13 of the last 17 French Open titles, although he would be the oldest champion ever if he wins this year  [1].  Nadal also recently won the Australian Open.  He is currently ranked fourth in the world, although Djokovic is currently ranked 2nd and won the French Open last year [2].  Still, barring injury or other reason for withdrawal, Nadal seems to have a good shot at the title.  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_French_Open_men%27s_singles_champions
[2] https://www.atptour.com/en/rankings/singles

Looking at Nadals history about 2/3rds of his wins have been at the French Open so there is something about it that suits him.  Also he’s been playing well recently and winning tournaments, so he’s still on form. Counter this is that he is in his mid thirties and while being a great player, time does start to tell and there is always injury, Covid or some new youngster to spoil the party.  Let alone chance.  In addition a he’d be making history again, and just that statement means it would be a rare event.  And on top of that he is on such a run of wins, it has to break at some point. Therefore giving a relatively low chance.

The crowd looks about right to me. On paper Nadal would be the clear favourite; he's won at Roland Garros 13 times, only losing three times since 2005. He won the Australian open recently after an epic 5-sets against Medvedev, against the odds and after a break due to injury, and covid. And then won again in Mexico. It seems the top players can benefit from a short forced break. So the case against him is whether he can maintain that winning streak at this late stage of his career, and whether Djokovic, Tsitsipas, Medvedev or someone else could create an upset. Perhaps Djokovic could some into form after missing Melbourne entirely and going out in the 4th at Dubai.

If Nadal's feet hold up I think he is pretty clear favourite out of the field. Nadal has been undefeated to start the year after coming back from a foot injury that held him out of competition for the last half of 2021. He will also be on Clay, his favourite surface and one that should be more forgiving on his feet than Hard. (He also has withdrawn from the Miami Open to give him more to recover in preparation for the French open, hopefully preserving the health of his feet). To add to this Djokovic -- who is expected to be his closest competition -- has not been playing competitively recents as a result of his COVID vaccination status. I would expect for him to take a little bit of time to get back into top form. Barring Nadal's foot giving out on him, it seems like the only thing standing in Nadal's path of another French Open title would be Djokovic surprisingly not missing a step or the emergence of a young new star at this tournament. I am leaving a 35% chance to cover these 3 cases.

We are in relatively unknown territory with this question in terms of statistical points of reference, no other athlete is close to Nadal on the clay format at the French Open in wins and streaks of wins as well as age while doing so.  However, using Borg's win tally we can take an outside view of the next best for all-time wins there.  Borg collected 6 titles between '74 and '81 between the ages of 18-25.  Another outside view is looking at all-time grand slam tourney winners (like the French Open) over 35 is very, very low (4). Attach and synthesize this to an inside view of Nadal's chances, I see it more likely than not he will once again win (66% yes).  However, the streak is such an outlier that the chances he will do so are not as certain as I would have expected.
This is Nadal's happy hunting ground so he must be the favorite so long as his body holds up.

When he competes in the French open he wins 80% of the time.  It seems ridiculously high for one person out of so many competitors, yet that seems to be the correct base rate.

Nadal is unbeaten this year and his record of wins at the French Open is freakishly consistent. It is only his injury proneness that significantly moderates my estimate of his probability of winning this year.
